child.publications: Voorhoeve, C L. 1975. West Papuan Phylum Languages on the Mainland of New Guinea: Bird's Head (Vogelkop) Peninsula. In Stephen A Wurm (ed.), Papuan languages and the New Guinea linguistic scene: New Guinea area languages and language study, vol. 1, 717-728. Canberra: Dept. of Linguistics, Research School of Pacific Studies, Australian National University.
child.pub-comments: "Barupasi is located 200 km north-west of Nabire" (Voorhoeve 1975: 872).

child.publications: Voorhoeve, C L. 1975. West Papuan Phylum Languages on the Mainland of New Guinea: Bird's Head (Vogelkop) Peninsula. In Stephen A Wurm (ed.), Papuan languages and the New Guinea linguistic scene: New Guinea area languages and language study, vol. 1, 717-728. Canberra: Dept. of Linguistics, Research School of Pacific Studies, Australian National University.
child.pub-comments: "Taŋgare is spoken near the township of Nabire at the bottom of the Geelvink Bay" (Voorhoeve 1975: 872).
child.geography: Nabire township at the bottom of the Geelvink Bay

child.publications: Voorhoeve, C L. 1975. West Papuan Phylum Languages on the Mainland of New Guinea: Bird's Head (Vogelkop) Peninsula. In Stephen A Wurm (ed.), Papuan languages and the New Guinea linguistic scene: New Guinea area languages and language study, vol. 1, 717-728. Canberra: Dept. of Linguistics, Research School of Pacific Studies, Australian National University.
child.pub-comments: "Bauri is spoken near Lake holmes in the mountains south-east of Baropasi" (Voorhoeve 1975: 872).
child.geography: Spoken near Lake holmes in the mountains south-east of Baropasi

child.publications: Voorhoeve, C L. 1975. West Papuan Phylum Languages on the Mainland of New Guinea: Bird's Head (Vogelkop) Peninsula. In Stephen A Wurm (ed.), Papuan languages and the New Guinea linguistic scene: New Guinea area languages and language study, vol. 1, 717-728. Canberra: Dept. of Linguistics, Research School of Pacific Studies, Australian National University.
child.pub-comments: "The total number of speakers in the phylum is not known, but may well be about 8,000" (Voorhoeve 1975: 872).

child.publications: Voorhoeve, C L. 1975. West Papuan Phylum Languages on the Mainland of New Guinea: Bird's Head (Vogelkop) Peninsula. In Stephen A Wurm (ed.), Papuan languages and the New Guinea linguistic scene: New Guinea area languages and language study, vol. 1, 717-728. Canberra: Dept. of Linguistics, Research School of Pacific Studies, Australian National University.
child.pub-comments: "Spoken just north of township of Serui on the south coast" (Voorhoeve 1975: 873).
child.geography: North of Serui township on the south coast

child.publications: Voorhoeve, C L. 1975. West Papuan Phylum Languages on the Mainland of New Guinea: Bird's Head (Vogelkop) Peninsula. In Stephen A Wurm (ed.), Papuan languages and the New Guinea linguistic scene: New Guinea area languages and language study, vol. 1, 717-728. Canberra: Dept. of Linguistics, Research School of Pacific Studies, Australian National University.
child.pub-comments: "Spoken on a small island about 10 km south-east of Serui" (Voorhoeve 1975: 873).
child.geography: Spoken on a small island about 10 km south-east of Serui

child.publications: Voorhoeve, C L. 1975. West Papuan Phylum Languages on the Mainland of New Guinea: Bird's Head (Vogelkop) Peninsula. In Stephen A Wurm (ed.), Papuan languages and the New Guinea linguistic scene: New Guinea area languages and language study, vol. 1, 717-728. Canberra: Dept. of Linguistics, Research School of Pacific Studies, Australian National University.
child.pub-comments: "Spoken in the mountainous interior of central Yapen" (Voorhoeve 1975: 873).

child.publications: Voorhoeve, C L. 1975. West Papuan Phylum Languages on the Mainland of New Guinea: Bird's Head (Vogelkop) Peninsula. In Stephen A Wurm (ed.), Papuan languages and the New Guinea linguistic scene: New Guinea area languages and language study, vol. 1, 717-728. Canberra: Dept. of Linguistics, Research School of Pacific Studies, Australian National University.
child.pub-comments: "With the almost total absence of structural information on the languages in question (the only exception being Sentani) it is difficult to assess the weight of the lexical evidence; the sporadic cases of phylum-level relationships with languages of the TGNP (Trans-New Guinea Phylum) and WPP (West Papuan Phylum) seem in themselves not enough to posit either TGNP or WPP membership for Yava, nor to unite the two phyla into one" (Voorhoeve 1975: 874-875). "Yava is spoken by more than 4,500; there are 15 dialects, some of them spoken in one village only" (Voorhoeve 1975: 873).
child.geography: is spoken in the middle section of Yapen island; in the west and east it borders on Austronesian languages, which take up the remainder of the island.

root.publications: Voorhoeve, C L. 1975. West Papuan Phylum Languages on the Mainland of New Guinea: Bird's Head (Vogelkop) Peninsula. In Stephen A Wurm (ed.), Papuan languages and the New Guinea linguistic scene: New Guinea area languages and language study, vol. 1, 717-728. Canberra: Dept. of Linguistics, Research School of Pacific Studies, Australian National University.
root.geography: The phylum stretches over a considerable part of the hinterland of the East Geelvink Bay
